translated: Jātaka🔽The Nine-Part Collection🔽The Vulture’s Peak
The Padakusala Youth Jātaka
“The learned one, the eloquent one,
the Ganges carries the pāṭali;
As it is being carried away, good sir,
give me one verse.”
“By which they sprinkle the suffering,
by which they sprinkle the sick,
in the middle of that I will die,
fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“Where seeds grow,
where beings are established,
that presses down on my head,
fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“By which they cook the food,
by which the cold is disturbed,
that burns my limbs,
fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“By which food they sustain themselves,
the many brahmins and nobles;
that food afflicts me,
fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“In the last month of summer,
the wise desire the wind;
that breaks my limbs,
fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“By which the world’s tree is supported,
this very fire releases;
“Divide the directions, Vakkaṅga,
for fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“I brought in the joy,
the garland-wearer, the sandalwood-anointed;
She has left me in the house,
for fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“I would rejoice in being born as,
and I would wish to be,
He has left me in the house,
for fear has arisen from the refuge.”
“Let the people of the country,
and the town-dwellers, listen to me;
Where there is water, there is fire,
where there is safety, there is danger.
The King is plundering the country,
and the royal chaplain;
Live self-controlled,
for fear has arisen from the refuge.”🔽The Padakusala Youth Birth Story is the sixth.
